item.title: A gradual approach on defence spending
item.description: Clues from the defence budget suggest India is gradually improving the operational efficiency of its armed forces, opting to tackle China without a rapid rise in expenditure

item.title: Global South unity can achieve climate justice
item.description: COP27 was a starting point for these crucial institutions to revise their priorities, and align and scale up funding. We will continue to urge MDBs to increase the deployment of climate finance three-fold until 2025

item.title: Can a credible offer of peace come from Pak?
item.description: A real shot at peace would be available only when an army chief, who has consolidated his position and can ride roughshod over domestic opposition, is convinced of the dire need to liberate the country’s economic resources from the military’s grip

item.title: US-China rivalry is ramping up
item.description: The United States’ move to down objects in the sky underlines anxiety about China and a hardening of stances

item.title: The Taste with Vir: Of restaurant explosion in India, celebrity chefs and future of dining
item.description: In this week's ‘The Taste’, Vir Sanghvi writes, “At many hotels, chefs who can barely run outlets become executive chefs. At too many restaurants, the chefs do not have the requisite experience but get hired anyway because the demand is so high.”

item.title: How India can strengthen its growing skill ecosystem
item.description: In the last eight years, the skill ecosystem has grown. Yet, along the way, flaws have crept into the system

item.title: Adani row: Yet another case of history repeating itself
item.description: For the past 66 years, we have witnessed some farce being repeated in politics. The debate over Adani Group and its political relations is nothing more than an episode in this never-ending series of farces

item.title: India can play a key role in climate cooperation
item.description: India took on a key position on the world stage by assuming the presidency of G20. This year, India will aim to provide leadership to a group of countries that comprises 85% of the world’s GDP and 60% of its population. Doing so will require determination, vision and courage. Today, Navroz K Dubash writes that India must use its presidency to push for greater cooperation to combat complex climate issues
